_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The knowledge gained by a mendicant who: They extend their mind toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings
They see sentient beings passing away and being reborn
They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds
They extend their mind toward knowledge of the ending of defilements
They truly understand the Four Noble Truths and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering and defilements
Their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance
They understand that rebirth is ended and the spiritual journey has been completed
The qualities of a mendicant who has end: They endure physical hardships and criticism
They are rid of greed, hate, and delusion, and purged of defects
They are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, hospitality, religious donations, and greeting with joined palms
They are the supreme field of merit for the world
The comparison between a mendicant who h: If a mendicant passes away without having ended the defilements, they’re considered as a mendicant who passed away untamed
If a mendicant passes away having ended the defilements, they’re considered as a mendicant who passed away tamed
